just one thing, this is NOT 1080p since the vertical resolution is cropped to 800 pixels.

This release is 800p.
lol @seyss6

1080P means 1920x1080 pixels. But if the aspect ratio is 2.4:1 there will be a black border on top and below. To decrease file size, that black border can be cropped, so that the picture only shows the actual movie. That's why it's 800 px. The main thing is that the 1920 width hasn't been tampered with.
This movie IS 1080p!

I love the fact that some people with no technical knowledge will tell other people that are video encoding experts that they're doing it wrong :P

1080p @ 16:9 is 1920x800
Any video is 1080p as long as it satisfies either 1920 pixels on horizontally or 1080 pixels vertically.

eg 1920x800 for 1:2.4 or 1440x1080 for 4:3

Tondre24: it is normal, the movie has been shot like that. It is same on dvd, you have movies that are 720x570, some others that are 720x400, look on this site, examples are everywhere.

The guy who make this rip could have done a 1920 x 1080 rip, yes and what would have been the result? Exactly the same, you would have had black border in top and bottom. 

Did you ever heard about a "crop"? There are black borders in top and bottom, the guy cut them, no need to let them in the movie. But in that case, the resolution is no longer 1920x1080 but 1920x800.

If you want to learn more or don't understand my explanations, go and read encoding video tutorials.

@ pmfabri
.MKV is the standard for quality.
.AVI is for quick, small rips .. usually if the source is crappy to begin with. 
But when ripping from BD or DVD, the standard is .MKV or .MP4.

To stream .MKV in Windows Media Player:
Option 1: manually register .MKV Codec.
Google "MKVs for Minimalists on Windows 7".

Option 2 (recommended):
Google "Shark007".

I used to manually register my codecs because i just don't like installing unnecessary codecs. But i soon realize it takes atleast 5 or 6 different type of Codecs to play modern media. It's much easier to install Shark's; 1 pack and you're set. it covers all popular audio and video formats: i.e. FLAC, APE, .MKV, .MP4, Subtitles, etc. 

Search on Google about Shark007's Codec.
I usually would recommend steering clear of Codec Packs, but Shark's Pack is truly quality and practical.

thank you very much!

I agree that anyone complaining about an mkv format needs to get a dose of reality on the popularity of vairying container files. However, I must make a correction that AVI's are simply for low quality videos. The container (extension) of the file has absolutely NO bearing on the quality of the video file in question. 
It is true that with many programs, different extensions give you different options for the quality of file. It is also true that MKV files typically have higher quality options than that of an AVI file. But the catch is that the quality of the container in question does not have any bearing on the actual container. The quality allowed in a container is determined by the program in question. With differing programs you can make and AVI file match the quality of any MKV file. The determining factors are your original video source and the encoding/ripping program. 
If you dont believe me, try it for yourself. Go and get the following programs (the first can be found on piratebay while the others are free) and give it a test:
Xilisoft (then choose whether you are ripping a DVD or a Blu-ray)
Handbrake
MediaCoder 2011

Enjoy, and make sure to always do your research before passing judgement!
